learning_outcomes.description: Engage in professional dialogue with international counterparts.
Study current practices to improve educational outcomes and enhance their career development.
Participate in networking opportunities with international educators/students.
Describe the similarities and differences between the educational systems in the host country and Australia.
Appreciate the culture of the host country.

assessments.task_description: Students will participate in the planned experiences that are part of the international field experience.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: There will be no grade penalty as this a pass/fail course
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.due_date:
20/02/2026 2:00 pm

Reflective journal will be submitted a week after returning.
assessments.task_description:
Assessment task one requires you to complete a reflective journal outlining your learning and engagement with a range of resources (presentations, readings, in-country experiences) across this course. Using the 'Five Rs' (Bain et al, 1999) to guide your reflections, you will undertake a process of thinking critically about your learning, your responses to the learning and how you will take that forward into your practice as a teacher in the future.

You should be reflecting on each day of the planned field experiences course. Ultimately, you will submit five topical reflections. It is expected that each reflection should be about a page. We are looking primarily for how you will take what you learned and use it in your professional practice moving forward.

The five topic areas are:

Cultural visits (Cultural/Heritage Tour, Raffles Place/Singapore River)

School Visits (SOTA, St. Joseph International, Raffles Girls Secondary)

Informal Education Sites (Singapore Art Museum, National Gallery, Art Science Museum)

Comparison of Education in Singapore and Australia: K-12 system AND Tertiary Initial Teacher Education

Summary Reflection—looking back on the whole experience and including thoughts on impact of learning about the history, culture, educational systems, social aspects on your future career paths


Five Rs (adapted from: Bain, Ballantyne, Packer & Mills, 1999) Reporting: what was the source of the learning?

Responding: what were your feelings towards the issue? what was your initial response?

Relating: how did the learning relate to your past and current personal and or professional experiences? why was it significant in the context of learning about Indigenous education?

Reasoning: what theories are relevant in helping to understand and critically reflect on the issue? why do you think you had the initial response and what factors impacted on this?

Reconstructing: why was this a significant learning experience for you as a teacher? how will you take this learning forward into practice?
assessments.submission_guidelines: Please submit electronically via Blackboard and using Turnitin.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: There will be no grade penalty as this a pass/fail course
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
13/02/2026

Presentation times will be arranged during the overseas experience.
assessments.task_description:
Working in a group of approximately 3 students, you will prepare a 15-to-20-minute presentation in which you will select an aspect of the field experience and describe how you could use that in your future classroom instruction. It could be something you learned about curriculum, pedagogical ideas, cultural inclusion, etc. Your group will need to:

1.     Describe the field experience aspect chosen.

2.     Explain how this could be used in your future instruction.

3.     Relate the aspect to either your area of specialization (primary) or content area (secondary).

4.     And be clear and engaging, with all group members equally participating in the presentation.

You will have time in the afternoons and evenings to work on this. It will be presented to the group during our final debrief on our last day in Singapore.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Group presentations will be made in person. Please refer to Blackboard or Course Coordinator for further instructions.
